title: Do you have any easy suggestions for an IA IB Math Exploration? - Quora

response.answer_text: I had 2 topics which were highly recommended by my teacher but I settled for something wayyy better. I’m an HL student. The first topic is trying to create an algorithm or suggest an approach to cracking passwords and/or credit card numbers using permutations. Second was, exploring Modular arithmetic (applying it as an arithmetic progression or applying it on Fermat’s Little Theorem). If none seem right, you could just approach an unsolved problem and analyse it to give a possible method to solve it. Also here is a link that has 200 topics Maths IA – Exploration Topics Hope you get it Fun With Modular Arithmetic or visit Khan Academy (link embedded) for a ground developement Easy Permutations and Combinations Fermat's Little Theorem

There is too many topics that you can find online which can be developed in an amazing math IA, I recommend you to follow this youtube channel and brows its interesting topics in Math Numberphile Personally I recommend you to discuss some unsolved theories and suggest a logical explanation that may be possible to be applied as a solution.For example: 1- Fermat’s Last theorem 2- Zeno’s Paradox3- Tangrams4- Golden Ration Don’t hesitate to contact me if you need any help :’) Best Wishes.

I was told to avoid anythings to do with statistics and probability, because it can be difficult to come up with conclusive end results. My maths teacher always recommended anything to do with sequences & series. I had a friend who investigated the algorithms associated with rubiks cubes, or another that liked music and so investigated the frequencies of sound waves. In general I’d recommend taking something relatively simple that you enjoy in real life, and ask yourself what kind of mathematical concepts can be applied to it :)

Anything with conditional probability/Bayes theorem. It’s easy and very applicable to real life scenarios (eg. healthcare, law etc.) Probability is very easy, and very easy to do well in. Just don’t choose the trite topics of football/soccer/penalty kicks and game theory/win-loss situations.

“Drain that pond” - modelling the time taken to drain a pond with different shapes of bottom. (cone, other?) I came across a news article a number of years ago about a person who killed all the fish in his pond. He drained the first foot in an hour, and the depth of the pond was 6 feet, so he came back 5 hours later to find the pond dry and all of the fish dead. A news article like this allows for a mathematical model to prove why the guy shouldn’t have waited so long, and then allows each student to explore slightly different models.
